body:
any updates/review?
@javelinjs
I'll review

Here is a solution:
Register IsMKLMem attribute to mkl dnn ops. then insert an op to copy data from mkl buffer to tblob whenever passing data from mkl dnn ops to non-mkldnn ops

The error for TEST1 is:
`ValueError: Unknown initialization pattern for softmax2_label. Default initialization is now limited to "weight", "bias", "gamma" (1.0), and "beta" (0.0).Please use mx.sym.Variable(init=mx.init.*) to set initialization pattern`
So basically mxnet thought labels are not provided but to be solved.

The error for TEST2 is:
`mxnet.base.MXNetError: [13:48:44] src/c_api/c_api_symbolic.cc:385: InferShapeKeyword argument name _1_softmax_label not found.`
and it does not work even if I provide the label names as _1_softmax_label and _2_softmax_label as in TEST1.

reduce your learning rate via:
python train_mnist.py --lr 0.05

please sync to latest version. the default lr is reduced to 0.05
A good job. Tensorflow implementation is similar. Maybe this should be co-designed with sparse weight push and pull in kvstore. #1237
I meet the same problem when i try to retrain inception-v3, is this problem be solved now?

Dear ap-hynninen and piiswrong,

Thank you for your help. By using the newest mxnet git version, I can now compile and run mxnet for gpu display card with computing capability 2.0.
I have tested it with the following example py.

`python2 train_mnist.py --network lenet --gpus 0`

My OS is arch linux with GCC version 6.3.1, CUDA 8.0.

I have to change the cuda_arch at config.mk to the following before compilation.

```
CUDA_ARCH := -gencode arch=compute_20,code=sm_20 \
		-gencode arch=compute_20,code=sm_21 \
		-gencode arch=compute_30,code=sm_30 \
		-gencode arch=compute_35,code=sm_35 \
		-gencode arch=compute_50,code=sm_50 \
		-gencode arch=compute_50,code=compute_50
```

I would suggest to change the default content of the config.mk to include the default support of computing capability 2.0 display card.

Thanks a lot!!

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html#create-a-data-iterator
http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/tutorial/bucketing.html

These links are broken

@Agoniii You can first try @howard0su's suggestion. If that doesn't work, you may need to run the following command and send me the output.
```bash
nosetests mxnet/tests/python/gpu/test_operator_gpu.py
```

@lisabug Due to the automatic slicing in the backward.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/executor_group.py#L431-L443
The slice is determined by the batch_size, which is assumed to be 3 in this example.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/executor_group.py#L210-L211
@precedenceguo

I didn't follow mxnet latest months and I see very recent commits in amalgation part. However you can try to remove #include <emmintrin.h> if it is present in your mxnet_predict-all.cc .
I managed to build more recent versions than mxnet js repo, more or less at the time when I modified the amalgation script through a pull request. But I didn't follow the subsequent changes.

@feiyulv I'm building the library without CUDA and CUDNN. I've added print line to 
```src/operator/convolution-inl.h``` and can confirm that I use indeed this source. May be it's necessary to switch off multi threaded execution to have more control over execution process. Does anybody know how to run mxnet in single thread mode?
```
Starting program: /usr/local/bin/python debug_conv.py
[New Thread 0x1403 of process 57061]
warning: unhandled dyld version (15)
[New Thread 0x1503 of process 57061]

Thread 3 received signal SIGTRAP, Trace/breakpoint trap.
[Switching to Thread 0x1503 of process 57061]
```
@howard0su  @sxjscience  I get the expected `Train-accuracy` runing with the `--lr 0.05`. Thanks very much.
@sxjscience: thanks! I never tested on the GPU. Amateur mistake.

Firstly you need to load ark data type to numpy array, you can try some parsing tools, the following one is a quite good 

https://github.com/vesis84/kaldi-io-for-python

After converting the data into numpy arrays, then you can write your own data iterator to manage the data loading process

Finally I was able to hit the specified break point. Before that I was trying to debug on MacOS, now I did the same on Ubuntu. I still don't know why debugging under MacOS brought no results, at least Ubuntu didn't let me down. 
@feiyulv thank you for hints and discussion.
Thanks a lot! VS2015 works!!! @yajiedesign

I get the same error on CPU version:
Is this because of CPU version? Do I need to change something in the model to be able to run it on CPU?


Error using callmxnet (line 26)
Assertion failed.

Error in mxnet.model/forward (line 136)
    callmxnet('MXPredCreatePartialOut', obj.symbol, ...

@lightningsoon As I said, I just forgot to add ssd extra_operators in config.mk.
```EXTRA_OPERATORS += example/ssd/operator``` will solve the problem.
Please follow our guideline for issue reporting. Please at least provide your `sessionInfo()`.

@edgarriba I think there are two concepts here. The CTensor which serves as memory handle(like pointer) which may not have memory management.

And a Container type that does memory management, hopefully via c++1x which wraps the C API. I think on that end. The requirement on dynamic size etc. is on the container type.
So the op will consume or write data only on the device type it finds in device_id right?

I think we are not yet very clear on operator specification. Especially, where does the context get set(e.g. cudaSetDevice), how to specify context resources(e.g. cuDNN handle).

- It can be done by a thread local workspace that can be mutated by setter(e.g. cublasSetStream)
- Alternatively, this can be done by an additional handle argument (which could make interface a bit more complicated)

LGTM, please update the branch.
try openblas instead of atlas
I'm not an expert, but i am pretty sure if you set all the weights to zero then a network is not able to learn anything (If that what you meant to do by setting the params to NULL)

I hope that setting subset of parameters to NULL will force some kind of default initialization during training process for these parameters (similar to `mxnet:::mx.init.uniform(0.1)` in  **jeremiedb**`s answer). Possibly I'm wrong.

There seems to be a conflict between opencv and python-opencv sometimes. You can
1. always import cv2 first
2. uninstall cv2
3. compile mxnet with USE_OPENCV=0
@precedenceguo thanks for the clarification, apologies for attempting to submit an incorrect patch!

I am attempting amalgamation on the most recent commit 39a2c0cff1be8b8277b2e0a8c55214acc186a49c and progressing beyond where I was getting before.  Unfortunately I'm not getting an error message, just simply a failure after a warning:

```
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc:17359:42: warning: comparison between signed and unsigned integer expressions [-Wsign-compare]
       if (static_cast<int>(ignore_label) == k) {
                                          ^
make: *** [jni_libmxnet_predict.o] Error 1
```
This is on a Mac.  On Linux it is breaking as well but with a different error:

```
In file included from jni/predictor.cc:4:0:
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc:22:26: fatal error: machine/ansi.h: No such file or directory
 #include <machine/ansi.h>
                          ^
compilation terminated.
Makefile:62: recipe for target 'jni_libmxnet_predict.o' failed
make: *** [jni_libmxnet_predict.o] Error 1
```

@piiswrong any ideas? 

@PhanTask I tried your recommended changes but still no success.

Are you using FreeBSD? Seems like a freebsd specific problem.

For mac, there should have been an error before the warning
How are you compiling it? You need -std=c++11. What's your compiler version?
That is in the CFLAGS for in the Makefiles in both /mxnet/amalgamation/ and /mxnet/nnvm/amalgamation/ . is that what you meant?
This setup (mac) amalgamates for v0.8.0, so I am assuming the setup is correct.

I see these errors in out.txt:
```
                         ^
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc: In member function 'virtual void dmlc::parameter::FieldEntry<double>::Set(void*, const string&) const':
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc:5196:25: error: 'stod' is not a member of 'std'
       this->Get(head) = std::stod(value);
                         ^
```

I think you compiler is not fully c++11 compliant. Try upgrading it.
Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't the compiler delivered in the standalone toolchain?
mxnet doesn't bring toolchain

Sorry, I meant the Android SDK standalone toolchain that is required to amalgamate for Android.  That's what I'm using.
https://developer.android.com/ndk/guides/standalone_toolchain.html#itc

1. What's the pros and cons defining two types `NDArray` and `SparseNDArray` vs defining one with a flag for type? Most frameworks seem to define them separately.

2. What's the precedence of sparse type when it's less clear?

3. Could we add a function `diag` similar to `scipy.sparse.csr_matrix.diagonal` and `scipy.sparse.diags` for extracting the diagonal of a matrix and making a diagonal matrix? They are often used. (It'd be even better if we largely model after the `scipy.sparse` interfaces.)
why remove all the >>>? It seems to be the standard way of displaying mixed python code and output
will do it today !
We had some discussions around this and turned out that due to >>>, it becomes difficult to copy paste the code for users while trying those examples. So, removed those.

Has there been complaints about this?
This is standard used every where for mixed data and code.
for example: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/user/basics.broadcasting.html

You can remove >>> for code that doesn't print anything

If you see this new changed link https://github.com/Roshrini/mxnet/blob/b1cd636be561b5443b47046bc1614177a4eb62e6/docs/api/python/kvstore.md

You can see if there is separate function without >>>, it becomes easy to just see input code block and then output code block just below that.
I also face this problem, running amalgamation Under Win32.

if I would like to utilize it on windows.
How could I make config.mk?
Thank you for your comment.

I also tried openblas, a similar error was reported,
Finally mkl works.

Thanks!
@feiyulv How about adding BlockGrad to the generated labels?
@sxjscience Yes. The automatic slicing itself caused the problem of backward on mean symbol since the output of mean symbol is a scalar instead of a tensor of size (b,).
@howard0su looks like the new bilinear tests are broken
@sxjscience Yes, it will solve this problem, but for the newers of mxnet, it will be easy to make a mistake and hard to debug
@feiyulv I think setting the label grad to zero is a good solution.
Seems not working, I replaced "B = mx.sym.broadcast_to(B, shape=(1, 3, 4, 4))" with "B = mx.sym.broadcast_to(B, shape=(0, 3, 0, 0))". Is this what you meant? I got "infer shape" error. @piiswrong

Hi @piiswrong.
The attached screenshot is training AlexNet in example/image-classification.
As you mentioned, the CPU2GPU copy has been achieved asynchronously as GPU/0 and GPU/1.
However, when I train AlexNet with 8 K80, the speedup compared to 1 GPU is only 3.7x.
Then, after profiling, I find loading data batch blocks the forward/backward operation like screenshot.
Hence, there is lots of idle time for GPUs.
The root cause is that the "crop" operations are only executed on a single **CPU** thread.
How do you think about running "crop" concurrently to improve the performance under multiple GPUs?
I may try to do in my leisure time.
Thanks.

![screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1085966/22727203/8902b1d4-ee12-11e6-9478-8396e1b75147.png)

I believe I found the solution: The issue is with the definition of the fit function. It binds the module like this:

`self.bind(data_shapes=train_data.provide_data, label_shapes=train_data.provide_label,
                  for_training=True, force_rebind=force_rebind)`

The problem is the data_shapes attribute: It does not allow to define any other data than the one provided by the data iterator. I have modified the fit function to accept a data_shape parameter, which is then passed to the bind function. This way I managed to solve my problem.

## There is a easy way to solve this problem 
And here's the code! 

under your rcnn file     ~/rcnn/

```javascript
# install cython
sudo pip install cython scikit-image easydict
# build cython extension
make
```

### problem solved!

>require(devtools)
install_version("DiagrammeR", version = "0.8.1", repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org")

Hi, you met this "error" because the R package uses a two-step installation method.

See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L299-L306

The NAMESPACE with two lines of code is the minimal package. After install it, you need to export all methods by `require(mxnet); mxnet:::mxnet.export("R-package")`.

Then help files can be generated by `require(roxygen2); roxygen2::roxygenise("R-package")`.
Can you show all the logs when compiling?

That sounds like it is going to be tricky.

Two general comments for the sparse ndarray, though there is a large number of engineer details we need to solve. 

1. As mentioned by @jli05, a single ndarray supporting both sparse and dense makes the interface clean, but it may confuse users. I'm prefer to give both (dense) NDArray and SparseNDArray to users so that they need to think about when should use sparse and when dense.

2. Between row sparse and COO, I suggest to have CSR. It is good for input 2D sparse data and weights for LDA.  It is more compact than COO, and may lead to better performance.

There is straightforward way to extend to `kvstore`: uses the row ID as the key, and then partition the rows into server nodes. It is less flexible than use the index tuple as key, because need to communicate a whole row rather than individual element. But communicating rows may be better for performance and is good enough for most algorithms. For implementation, we only need to update the kvstore implementation without changing ps-lite.

@d4wud I met the same problem but I solved it by recreating NDK toolchain. You can try to recreate Standalone Toolchain with libc++ headers and libraries since the GNU STL library(libstdc++, by default) seems to not fully support c++11 features(such as function stod stoi stof to_string).

Thanks OwlECoyote for pointing out the bias argument. 
Effectively, the R feedforward module is designed so as to either initialize all the arguments or take the full and complete list of arguments in the arg.params. 

Lines 416-417 in /model.R should make the behavior of the model clearer: 

```
params <- mx.model.init.params(symbol, input.shape, initializer, mx.cpu())
if (!is.null(arg.params)) params$arg.params <- arg.params
```

To make the picture clearer, the Feedforward wrapper calls the model.train function which initiates the arg.params to 0 before assigning the Pre-trained arg.params. Therefore, if there are missing arguments like statist-bhfz mentionned, their weights will be "initialised" to 0. In this case, the model will run, but won't learn, so it's not a good idea! 

Bottom line: arg.params, if provided, should simply be list containing the ndarrays for each of the model arguments (symbol$arguments, excluding data and label). And such list must have its names match the model arguments names.

@d4wud Adding param '--stl=libc++' when running ```python make_standalone_toolchain.py``` works to me.
For more details:
https://github.com/android-ndk/ndk/issues/82#issuecomment-236979264
https://developer.android.com/ndk/guides/cpp-support.html
